results.title: La Baie des Anges = Bay of Angels
results.brief_description:
An ordinary bank clerk who has had a streak of good luck at the Nice casino, falls in love with a compulsive gambler, who has left a husband and child to satisfy her craving. Shot very quickly on the French Riviera, this love story with a roulette wheel as the motif and the motive, is one of the most vivid evocations of gambling fever on film. The luminous photography and the hypnotic music add to the film’s attraction. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producer, Paul-Edmond Decharme ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Michel Legrand, art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Claude Mann, Paul Guers.

results.title: Les Deux Anglaises et le Continent = Anne and Muriel
results.brief_description:
Based on Roche’s autobiographical second novel, ‘Two English Girls’ is an inverted version of Jules and Jim set in the Belle Epoque with two English girls, sisters of very different temperament, throughout their lives loving the same man - a Frenchman. Truffaut’s alter ego, Leaud, brings his persona of solitariness and passivity to the character of Claude at the apex of the triangle. Although both films are about wasted lives, ‘Two English Girls’ is sadder and more complex than Jules and Jim which is dominated by “Moreau’s charismatic capriciousness which spills all over the movie”, to quote Pauline Kael, giving it more vitality. ‘Two English Girls’, with its detached narration, is more introspective, dealing with emotions at one remove - ‘feelings about feelings’.

Credits: Director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Jean Gruault ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Leaud, Kika Markham, Stacey Tendeter.

results.title: The Naked lunch
results.creator_credit: David Cronenberg, Jeremy Thomas, Naked Lunch Productions and Recorded Picture Company
results.brief_description: William Burrough’s novel “The Naked Lunch” is one of the most acclaimed of Beat Generation writings. The visionary horror director, David Cronenberg, combines film-noir, horror and science-fiction to recreate Burrough’s expressionistic journey into a writer’s soul: an examination of the terrifying link between insanity and artistic inspiration. In a dream-like North African city, a group of American writers and artists immerse themsleves in drugs and sex, and occassionally in their artistic pursuits. Based closely on Burrough’s relationship with his wife - whom he accidentally killed - “The Naked Lunch”, though a novel that owes much to the grammar of cinema, was long considered unfilmable. Cronenberg’s attempt is audacious and ultimately successful. With Judy Davis, Peter Weller, Julian Sands and Roy Scheider. The haunting musical score is by Ornette Coleman.

results.title: Continental Circus
results.brief_description:
The racing careers and exploits of two contrasting characters are explored in this French documentary about small motorcycle racing. One is the Australian Jack Findlay, who manages to stay in the game through sheer spunk and the help of his French wife and many friends. He often has accidents, lacks a corporate sponsor, and sometimes must borrow even the machines he races with. Giacomo Agostini, on the other hand, seems to be singularly blessed. As the reigning champion (in 1971) and a noteworthy playboy, he has all the sponsorship he could ask for, and wins his races without injuries or spills. This film highlights the difficulty and even fatal dangers of this form of racing. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1972.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Zajderman ; director, Jerome Laperrousaz ; writer, Jerome Laperrousaz ; photography, Jimmy Glasberg, Jean-Paul Jansen, Raymond Meyer ; music, Gong.
Cast: Jack Findlay, Nanou, Giacomo Agostini.

results.title: Things to come. The Invisible man
results.creator_credit: James Whale, William Cameron Menzies, Alexander Korda, Carl Laemmle Jnr, London Film Productions and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Featured in this collector’s set are two famous films adapted from the works of H. G. Wells. “Things To Come”: Wells’ futuristic vision of impending global war and it’s strange effects for mankind. When world war erupts a brilliant scientist decides to start a new ‘Scientific Order” governed by scientists. Stars Ralph Richardson and Raymond Massey. “The Invisible Man”: This version starring Claude Raines in his film debut is the most faithful to Wells’ novel. As with the original novel the film retains the unique blend of horror, strange pathos, sublime black humour and the ever-engaging curiosity. Includes a talk by Orson Welles on “The War of the worlds”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Whale, William Cameron Menzies, Alexander Korda, Carl Laemmle Jnr, London Film Productions and Universal Pictures

results.title: L'ombre Rouge = the Red Shadow
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Comolli, Claudio Bondi and Marin Karmitz
results.brief_description:
In April 1937, Anton, a Soviet spy, is captured in Paris. Anton is involved in gun smuggling activities for the benefit of the Spanish Republican Army. He is taken to Bavaria to be exchanged against Muller, a double agent.

Credits: Producers, Marin Karmitz, Claudio Bondi ; director, Jean-Louis Comolli ; writers, Jean Louvet, Gerard Guicheteau, Claudio Bondi, Jean-Louis Comolli ; photography, William Lubtchansky ; music, Michel Portal.
Cast: Claude Brasseur, Nathalie Baye, Jacques Dutronc, Andrea Ferreol, Alexandre Arbatt, Pascal Bonitzer, Patrick Depeyrat.

results.title: La Mort En Direct = Death Watch
results.brief_description:
Roddy, a TV cameraman has a camera implanted in his brain and is assigned by a ruthless TV producer to follow the slow agony of a mortally ill woman, Katherine Mortenhoe. His footage will then be run on the popular TV series, ‘Death Watch’. Katherine knows she is condemned by an incurable illness. While the TV station is only interested in ratings and the grim spectacle of what goes on inside the brain of someone who knows she’s doomed, Roddy becomes increasingly compassionate and disgusted by the tawdriness of his assignment as he comes to know Katherine better. Sadly, all the English speaking actors are dubbed in French in this particular version.

Credits: Producers: Elie Kfouri, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Bertrand Tavernier, David Rayfel ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Harvey Keitel, Harry Dean Stanton, Therese Liotard, Max von Sydow, Bernhard Wicki.

results.title: Rain
results.creator_credit: Lewis Milestone, Joseph Schenck and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Joan Crawford stars as prostitute Sadie Thompson, in this version of Somerset Maugham’s story of lust in the sultry Pacific. From her first entrance, ring-studded hand on a door jamb, followed by an undulating body in a skin tight checked outfit, Crawford dominates the film as she goes on to seduce Walter Huston’s stern straight-laced missionary. The variable quality of the soundtrack is due to the quality of the original film and is not the fault of the video.

results.title: The Graduate
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Lawrence Turman, Embassy Pictures Corporation (US) and Lawrence Turman Inc
results.brief_description: Dustin Hoffman stars as college graduate Benjamin Braddock, who spends his first summer out of school being seduced by the wife of his father’s best friend. He also falls in love with the woman’s daughter to further complicate his life. Nominated for 7 Academy Awards, The Graduate won the Oscar for Best Direction, (Mike Nichols), and its brilliant score by Simon and Garfunkle won 3 Grammies. Ann Bancroft is the memorable Mrs. Robinson, with Katherine Ross as her daughter and rival for Benjamin’s affection. “The Graduate” is a modern comedy classic to be enjoyed again and again.

results.title: Le Battant = the Cache
results.creator_credit: Alain Delon, Adel Productions and AMLF
results.brief_description:
As soon as he is released from jail, Jacques Darnay is being followed by Commissioner Rouxel. Darnay has spent 5 years inside for a jewellery heist and Rouxel hopes Darnay is going to lead him to the cache.

Credits: Producer, director, Alain Delon ; writers, Alain Delon, Christopher Frank ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Christian Dorisse, Michel Colombier.
Cast: Alain Delon, Francois Perier, Pierre Mondy, Anne Parillaud, Andrea Ferreol, Jean-Francois Garreaud, Richard Anconina, Michel Beaune.
